source.name: Brisbane City Council
source.notes: Based on official Brisbane City Council recycling guidelines. Yellow-lid bin for recyclables. Cardboard coffee cups accepted (unusual!). Firm plastics only. Brisbane Bin and Recycling app.

materials.name: Newspaper
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
No need to bundle or tie
notes: Do not bag in plastic — items must be loose in the bin
commonMistakes: Don't bag newspapers in plastic bags
Don't include heavily soiled or wet newspaper

materials.name: Junk mail and brochures
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Glossy and non-glossy mail both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include if laminated or plastic-coated

materials.name: Office paper
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Includes white and coloured paper
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels, tissues, or napkins
Don't include waxed or plastic-coated paper

materials.name: Coloured paper
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: All colours of paper accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include if laminated or plastic-coated
Don't include paper with glitter or heavy glue

materials.name: Gift wrapping paper
instructions: Remove tape, ribbons, and bows
Place paper loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Only non-metallic, non-foil wrapping paper is accepted
Do the scrunch test — if it stays scrunched, it's paper and can be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't include metallic or foil wrapping paper — that goes in general waste
Don't include cellophane

materials.name: Glossy paper
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Glossy coated paper from advertisements and magazines is accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include photographs — photo paper has a plastic coating

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
instructions: Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
Staples can stay in
notes: Glossy and non-glossy magazines both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Envelopes
instructions: Place in the yellow-lid bin
Window envelopes accepted — no need to remove the plastic window
notes: Small plastic windows are fine
commonMistakes: Don't include padded envelopes with bubble wrap lining — those go in general waste

materials.name: Phone books
instructions: Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Can be placed whole — no need to remove the spine
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Greeting cards
instructions: Remove any embellishments (glitter, ribbons, batteries)
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Plain paper and cardboard greeting cards accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include musical cards with batteries — remove the battery component and put it in hazardous waste
Don't include heavily glittered cards

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
Remove packing materials (bubble wrap, foam, packing peanuts)
notes: Large boxes should be flattened and cut down to fit in the bin
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard heavily soaked with grease or food — that goes in general waste
Flatten boxes to save space in the bin

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
instructions: Empty the carton
Leave the lid on
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Gable-top and Tetra Pak cartons both accepted
Includes juice boxes, long-life milk, soup and broth cartons
commonMistakes: Don't flatten — leave three-dimensional for sorting

materials.name: Cereal and food boxes
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove plastic liners inside
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Thin cardboard (boxboard) accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic bags and liners from inside
Don't include wax-coated boxboard

materials.name: Pizza boxes
instructions: Empty the box and remove food scraps
Flatten and place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Brisbane accepts pizza boxes even with minor grease stains
Tear off and discard heavily soiled portions
commonMistakes: Don't include the box if it has large amounts of food stuck to it

materials.name: Toy boxes
instructions: Remove plastic windows and inserts
Flatten the cardboard
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Cardboard component only — plastic packaging goes in general waste if it's soft/film plastic
commonMistakes: Don't include cable ties, plastic inserts, or foam padding

materials.name: Detergent and tissue boxes
instructions: Empty the box
Flatten
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Remove plastic liner bags from detergent boxes
commonMistakes: Don't include the inner plastic bag — that goes in general waste

materials.name: Cardboard coffee cups
instructions: Empty the cup
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Brisbane specifically accepts cardboard coffee cups for recycling — this is unusual compared to most Australian councils
Plastic lids from coffee cups also go in the yellow-lid bin (firm plastic)
commonMistakes: Don't include foam/polystyrene cups — those go in general waste
Empty any remaining liquid before recycling

materials.name: Plastic soft drink bottles
instructions: Empty the bottle
Leave the lid on
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Firm/rigid plastic bottles accepted
Eligible for 10c refund via Containers for Change (QLD Container Refund Scheme)
commonMistakes: Don't crush — sorting machines identify shape
Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Plastic milk and juice bottles
instructions: Empty the bottle
Leave the lid on
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Firm/rigid plastic — accepted in Brisbane
commonMistakes: Don't need to rinse — just empty

materials.name: Plastic takeaway containers
instructions: Empty the container
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Firm/rigid plastic takeaway containers accepted
Must be rigid — if you can scrunch it, it's soft plastic and goes in general waste
commonMistakes: Don't include foam/polystyrene containers — those go in general waste
Don't include soft plastic film lids

materials.name: Margarine and butter containers
instructions: Empty the container
Leave the lid on
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Firm plastic container — accepted
commonMistakes: Don't need to wash — just empty

materials.name: Yoghurt tubs
instructions: Empty the tub
Leave the lid on
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Firm plastic dairy containers accepted
Brisbane says leave lids on
commonMistakes: Don't need to wash — just empty

materials.name: Biscuit and sushi trays
instructions: Empty the tray
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Firm/rigid plastic trays accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include soft plastic wrappers around the tray — those go in general waste

materials.name: Detergent and shampoo bottles
instructions: Empty the bottle
Leave the lid on
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Firm plastic bottles accepted
Trigger spray bottles also accepted — leave the trigger on
commonMistakes: Don't need to rinse — just empty

materials.name: Disposable plastic plates and cups
instructions: Empty and place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Firm/rigid disposable plastic plates and cups accepted in Brisbane
Must be rigid plastic — not foam/polystyrene
commonMistakes: Don't include foam/polystyrene plates or cups
Don't include soft or flexible film plastic

materials.name: Glass bottles
instructions: Empty the bottle
Leave the lid on
Must be whole and unbroken
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: All colours of glass accepted
Many bottles eligible for 10c refund via Containers for Change
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in general waste
Don't include drinking glasses, Pyrex, or ceramics

materials.name: Glass jars
instructions: Empty the jar
Leave the lid on
Must be whole and unbroken
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include broken jars — wrap and place in general waste
Don't include ceramic containers or Pyrex

materials.name: Aluminium cans
instructions: Empty the can
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Eligible for 10c refund via Containers for Change (QLD Container Refund Scheme)
No need to rinse — just empty
commonMistakes: Don't crush — sorting machines identify shape
Don't put cans inside plastic bags

materials.name: Steel and tin cans
instructions: Empty the can
Leave the lid on (push it inside if detached)
Place loose in the yellow-lid bin
notes: No need to rinse — just empty
Steel cans are magnetically separated at the recycling facility
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be empty
Leave the lid on
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Empty aerosol cans accepted
Do not puncture or crush
commonMistakes: Don't include partially full aerosol cans — they are hazardous
Don't puncture or crush

materials.name: Aluminium foil
instructions: Scrunch foil into a ball at least the size of a tennis ball
Place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Small pieces fall through sorting machines — scrunch into a ball first
Must be free of food
commonMistakes: Don't put small flat pieces of foil in — scrunch them into a ball first
Don't include foil-lined packaging (e.g. chip packets) — that's not pure foil

materials.name: Aluminium pie trays
instructions: Empty and wipe out food residue
Scrunch or place in the yellow-lid bin
notes: Aluminium foil trays and pie trays accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include if heavily contaminated with baked-on food

materials.name: Soft plastics and plastic bags
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Soft plastics are NOT accepted in Brisbane's yellow-lid bin
If you can scrunch it into a ball, it's soft plastic
Some supermarkets have REDcycle soft plastic drop-off bins
commonMistakes: Never put soft plastics in the yellow-lid bin — they tangle sorting machinery
Never bag your recycling in plastic bags

materials.name: Polystyrene and foam
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Not accepted in Brisbane's yellow-lid bin
Includes foam food trays, cups, and packaging
commonMistakes: Don't put foam trays in the yellow-lid bin even if they have a recycling symbol
Don't include packing peanuts in recycling

materials.name: Nappies
instructions: Bag and place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin
Don't put in the green-lid bin

materials.name: Food-contaminated recyclables
instructions: If an item has significant food residue and cannot be emptied, place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Brisbane says to empty containers but washing is not required
A small amount of residue is OK
commonMistakes: Don't put items full of food in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Broken glassware and crockery
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper
Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Broken glass contaminates recycling
Only whole, unbroken glass bottles and jars go in the yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put broken glass in the yellow-lid bin
Wrap sharp edges to protect waste collectors

materials.name: Ceramics and crockery
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
Donate if still usable
notes: Ceramics cannot be recycled with container glass — different melting point
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Drinking glasses and glassware
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
Donate if still usable
notes: Different glass composition to bottles — contaminates recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put drinking glasses in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Tissues and paper towels
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Too contaminated for paper recycling
Used paper towels and napkins go in general waste
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Plastic straws and cutlery
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Too small for sorting machinery
QLD has banned single-use plastic straws, stirrers, cutlery, and plates
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Food wrappers and snack packets
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Metallised plastic film cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Cling wrap and glad wrap
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Soft plastic — not accepted in the yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Light bulbs (incandescent and LED)
instructions: Wrap carefully
Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: CFL and fluorescent tubes are hazardous — take to a drop-off point
commonMistakes: Don't put in the yellow-lid bin
Don't confuse with CFL bulbs which need special disposal

materials.name: Thermal receipts
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Thermal paper contains BPA — contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put receipts in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
notes: Not accepted in the green-lid organics bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green-lid bin

materials.name: Damaged clothing and shoes (non-donatable)
instructions: Place in the general waste (dark red-lid) bin
If still wearable, donate instead
notes: Only truly damaged, non-donatable items go in general waste
commonMistakes: Donate if still usable — don't throw away wearable clothing

materials.name: Food scraps
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
Use a kitchen caddy with compostable liner to collect scraps
notes: Brisbane's green-lid bin accepts all food waste including meat, dairy, and cooked food
Green-lid bin is collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags — only certified compostable liners
Don't put food in general waste if you have green-lid bin service

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
notes: All fruit and vegetable scraps accepted
commonMistakes: Remove fruit stickers and rubber bands

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
Wrap in newspaper to reduce odour
notes: Brisbane's industrial composting handles meat and bones
Includes raw and cooked meat, poultry, fish, seafood shells, and bones
commonMistakes: Don't put in general waste if you have green-lid service
Wrap in newspaper, not plastic

materials.name: Bread, pasta, and rice
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
notes: All grain products accepted
commonMistakes: Remove plastic packaging first

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
Paper coffee filters accepted
notes: Paper tea bags break down well in composting
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic-mesh or nylon tea bags

materials.name: Eggshells
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
notes: Crush for faster breakdown
commonMistakes: No need to wash

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
notes: Recycle the container separately in the yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put the container in the green-lid bin — only the food waste

materials.name: Garden waste
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
Large branches: cut to fit or book a free green waste drop-off
notes: Green-lid bin accepts garden organics alongside food
commonMistakes: Don't include soil, rocks, or treated timber
Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Grass clippings and leaves
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
notes: Green and dry leaves both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic — place loose in the bin

materials.name: Food-soiled paper and cardboard
instructions: Place in the green-lid organics bin
notes: Food-contaminated paper goes in the green-lid bin, not the yellow-lid bin
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the yellow-lid bin

materials.name: Certified compostable bin liners
instructions: Use Australian Standard AS 4736 certified compostable bags only
Place filled liner in the green-lid organics bin
notes: Only bags with the Australian seedling logo are accepted
Regular plastic bags labelled 'biodegradable' are NOT accepted
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags — even ones marked 'degradable'
Must be AS 4736 certified with the seedling logo

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a battery drop-off point (Officeworks, Battery World, Bunnings, Aldi)
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
Never put in any kerbside bin
notes: Batteries cause fires in waste trucks — NEVER put in any bin
B-cycle program for free battery recycling at major retailers
commonMistakes: Never put batteries in any kerbside bin
Tape terminals to prevent short circuits

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Paintback drop-off point
Bunnings participates in the free Paintback program
notes: Paintback is a free national paint recycling program
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to a participating workshop or council waste facility
Many mechanics accept used oil
notes: Used oil can be re-refined
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or on ground

materials.name: Household chemicals
instructions: Take to a council Household Chemical CleanOut event
Keep in original containers
Check brisbane.qld.gov.au for upcoming collection events
notes: Never mix chemicals
Brisbane City Council runs free Household Chemical CleanOut events
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Gas bottles and cylinders
instructions: Take to a gas supplier or council waste facility
Never put in any kerbside bin
notes: Pressurised containers are explosion risks in waste trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes and CFL bulbs
instructions: Take to a participating retailer (Bunnings) or council waste facility
Handle carefully — contains mercury
notes: FluoroCycle program — free drop-off at Bunnings
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Don't break them — mercury is hazardous

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Return to any pharmacy — RUM (Return Unwanted Medicines) program
Pharmacies accept expired or unwanted medications for free
notes: RUM Project is a free national program
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Take to a council e-waste drop-off or waste transfer station
Delete personal data before disposal
Check brisbane.qld.gov.au for locations
notes: E-waste contains valuable recoverable materials
Brisbane City Council runs free e-waste collection events
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Wipe personal data first

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to charity shops (Vinnies, Salvos, Red Cross, Lifeline)
Place in charity clothing bins
Only donate clean, dry items in good condition
notes: Brisbane has many charity bins and op shops
commonMistakes: Don't put in any kerbside bin
Don't donate wet or heavily soiled items

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Book a free kerbside large item collection via Brisbane City Council
Or take to a council waste transfer station
notes: Brisbane City Council offers free on-request large item collection
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Remove doors from fridges for safety

materials.name: Tyres
instructions: Take to a tyre retailer or council waste facility
Most tyre shops accept old tyres when you buy new ones
notes: Tyres are banned from landfill
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Don't put in any kerbside bin

materials.name: Containers for Change (10c refund)
instructions: Take eligible containers to a Containers for Change depot or reverse vending machine
Eligible containers have a 10c refund mark
Find your nearest depot at containersforchange.com.au
notes: QLD Container Refund Scheme gives 10c per eligible container
Most aluminium cans, glass bottles, plastic bottles, and small cartons are eligible
Wine bottles, plain milk containers, and cordial over 1L are NOT eligible
commonMistakes: Not all containers are eligible — look for the 10c mark
Don't crush containers — barcode needed for scanning

recycle: Paper — newspaper, junk mail, brochures, office paper, gift wrapping, glossy paper, magazines, envelopes, phone books, greeting cards, coloured paper
Cardboard — boxes, milk/juice cartons, cereal/pizza/toy boxes, detergent/tissue boxes, cardboard coffee cups
Firm plastics — soft drink bottles, takeaway containers, margarine tubs, milk/juice bottles, yoghurt tubs, biscuit/sushi trays, detergent/shampoo bottles, disposable plates/cups
Glass bottles and jars — whole and unbroken, leave lids on
Metal — steel/aluminium cans, aerosol cans (empty), aluminium foil (scrunched), pie trays
compost: All food scraps — fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, grains, seafood
Coffee grounds, paper tea bags, paper filters
Garden waste — prunings, weeds, grass clippings, leaves, palm fronds
Certified compostable bin liners (AS 4736 seedling logo only)
trash: Soft plastics, plastic bags, cling wrap, bubble wrap
Broken glassware, ceramics, crockery, drinking glasses

compost: Regular plastic bags (even if labelled biodegradable)

tips: Brisbane has three bins: yellow-lid (recycling), green-lid (organics), dark red-lid (general waste)
Leave lids on bottles and containers — Brisbane accepts items with lids on
Empty containers but no need to wash or rinse — just empty and dry
All items must be placed LOOSE in the bin — never bag recyclables
Cardboard coffee cups can go in the yellow-lid bin — Brisbane is one of the few councils that accepts them
Only FIRM plastics go in the yellow-lid bin — if you can scrunch it, it's soft plastic and goes in general waste
Scrunch aluminium foil to at least tennis ball size before placing in the yellow-lid bin
Use the Brisbane Bin and Recycling app to check what goes where
QLD Containers for Change gives 10c refund for eligible containers (containersforchange.com.au)
If in doubt, put it in the general waste bin to avoid contaminating recycling

locations.name: Containers for Change Depots
locations.notes: 10c refund per eligible container. Multiple depots and reverse vending machines across Brisbane.

locations.name: Bunnings (various locations)
locations.notes: Free drop-off for CFL/fluorescent tubes and paint. Multiple Brisbane locations.

locations.name: Charity Clothing Bins (Vinnies, Salvos, Lifeline)
locations.notes: Located throughout Brisbane metro area. Only donate clean, dry items in wearable condition.

locations.name: Brisbane City Council Transfer Stations
locations.notes: Council operates multiple waste transfer stations. Check website for locations, hours, and accepted items.
